May 6, 1939
TRANS-ATIANTIC FIRST FLIGHT COVERS
The United States Post Office Department hes announced in the Postal Bulletin
of May 5, 1939 the conditions under which first flight covers to be carried on the
first Trans-Atlentic Air Mail Service, may be obtrined by all who are interested in
these first flight covers.
In view of the possible difficulties which msy be encountored by Philate-
lists in the United States, Canada, Bermuda or other countries in securing covers to
be posted in the Abores, Portugsl or. France, for carriage on the first flight of this
service, the Pan American Airwys agrees to accept consignments of covers to be posted
in these foreign countrics.
In this connection it should be clearly understood by all who avail them-
selves of this service thet the offer of Pan Imerican Airways is limited to accepting
consignnents of covers in the United States, forwerding these covers to European points
of origin, affixing the necessary foreign postage to ench cover, and positing some
in the local post office before the clusing time for this mail, as fixea by the lucel
Post Office.
Acceptance by the Company in New Yurk of these covers does not cunstitute
a guarantee that the covers will be carried frum Europe on the first flight.
In the
event these covers arrive too late in Europe to be carried, they will be returned to
the sender by ordinary nail with a refund of the amount received, less a hanüling charge
of 15 cents per cover.
OFFER OF SERVICE BY PAN AMERICIN AIRWAYS
The Pan Americen Lirways will accept at its ffice in New York, consignnents
(Philatelic Section), 135 Ecst 42nd Street, New York, N. Y., and should reach the Pan
American Airways on or before May 16th, 1939.
These
consignments of covers must be
accompanied by money orcers mace payable to Pon Anerican Airweys, New York, N. Y., for
the tutal amount of service desired by the sencer at the prices quited beluw, per cover.
SERVICE AVAILADIE AND PREPARATION OF COVERS
Sencers may acdress their covers to thenselves or other persons in the United
states or elsewhere.
Ench cover must be plainly marked, in the upper left hand corner,
to incicate the service aesired, that is
Covers to be postea in Azores Istancs:

"Hurta to Marseilles"

June 8, 1939.
FIRST FLIGHT COVER SERVICE VIA THE NORTH TRANSATLANTIC AIR MAIL SERVICE
The United States Post Office Department has announced the inauguration
of Air Mail Service over the Northern route of the Transatlantic Air Mail Service
from New York, N. Y. to Southampton, England, via Shediac, Now Brunswick; Botwood,
Newfoundland; and Foynes, Ireland.
In view of the possible difficulties which may be encountered by Phil-
atelists or Collectors in the United States or other countries in securing first
flight covers to be posted and carried on the first flight of this service from
New Brunswick, Newfoundland, Ireland or England to other points, Pan American
Airways offers to cooperate as follows:
SERVICE BY PAN AMERICAN AIRWAYS
Pan American Airvays will accept at its New York Office, consignment of
first flight covers to be posted and carried on the first flight of the Northern
Route of the Transatlantic Air Mail Service.
All covers for the service must be
forwarded in a separate container to Philatelic Soction, Pan American Airways,
135 E. 42nd St.
These
consignments of covers must be accompanied by money order
or certified checks, made payable to Pan American Airways, New York, N.Y.
for
the total amount of service desired by the sender, at the prices quoted below.
It is also requested that the sender include with the covers an itemized list
of the services desired.
SERVICE AVAILABLE, PREPARATION OF COVER, CLOSING TIME FOR COVERS
Senders may address their covers to themselves or other persons in the
United States or elsewhere.
EACH COVER MUST BE PLAINLY ENDORSED BY THE SENDER
ACCORDING TO SERVICES DESIRED, These endorsements should be placed in the upper
left-hand corner of each cover as follows:
Endorsement on covers to be posted in New Brunswick:
New Brunswick to Newfoundland)
New Brunswick to Ireland
New Brunswick to England
New Brunswick to U.S.A.
)
Covers must be received by Pan American
Airways by June 18, 1939.
Covers must be received by Pan American

POSTAGE STAMPS CANNOT BE ACCEPTED IN PAYMENT FOR THESE SERVICES.
SPECIAL CONDITIONS
1.
It must be clearly understood by all who avail
themselves of this
service that the offer of Pan American Airways is limited to accepting consign-
ments of covers in the United States, forwarding them to points where sender
desires same posted, in accordance with his endorsement on cover,
and deposit-
ing the covers in the local post office before the closing time for this mail,
as fixed by the local post office.
Acceptance by the Company in New York of
these covers does not constitute a guarantee that the covers will be carried
on the first flight.
Covers arriving too late to be serviced will be returned
to sender.
In the event that the Company forwards the covers from New York
to the point where
they are to be posted,
but due to any circumstances arrive
too late at the points to be serviced on the first flight, they will be re-
turned to the sender with a refund of the amount received, less a handling
charge of 154 per cover.
2.
Round trip covers cannot be accepted or serviced.
Only individual
covers from one point to another will be serviced by the Company. Pan American
Airways also gives notice that it cannot fix special stamps or blocks of stamps
on covers,
to meet the wishes of collectors,
but will affix only the regular
authorized foreign stamps on the covers.
Covers with foreign postage already
affixed on the
covers by the senders cannot be accepted by the Company.
These
covers
should be sent direct by the sender to the Post Office where same are to
be posted.
Requests for crew autographs on the covers will not be considered
or granted.
3.
Covers to be posted in the United States and destined to New Brunswick,
Newfoundland,
Ireland or England must not be sent to the Company.
These covers
must be forwarded to the Postmaster, New York, N.Y., under cover specifically
requesting that they be held for the first North Transatlantic Air Mail Service.
For rates
and other details of this service consult your local Postmaster.
4.
The Newfoundland and British Postal Administrations have advised that
no cachet will be affixed on covers posted at their offices. Pon American Air-
ways will endeavor to affix a special commemorative cachet on all covers han-
dled by the Company from these points.
The British Post Office also gives
notice that it will not backstamp covers arriving there. All other Postal
Administrations indicate they will back stamp covers.

- 3 -
IMPORTANT
Covers intended for ultimate delivery to points beyond Newfoundland
or New Brunswick which are to be posted in England or Ireland and are en-
dorsed in the upper left-hand corner for air service "England to Newfoundland",
"England to New Brunswick",
to Newfoundland"! or
"Ireland to New
Brunswick", must bear not only the address of person at ultimate destination,
but must also be addressed "Care of Pan American Airways, Botwood,
Newfound-
land" or
"Care of Pan American Airways,
Moncton, Canada, "in order to comply
with English and Irish postal regulations.
A typical address for such covers would be as follows:
"England to Newfoundland"
Stamp
Mr. John Doe,
417 East Center Street,
Marion, Ohio.
c/o Pan American Airways,
Botwood, Newfoundland.
The address of such sender should appear on the back of these en-
velopes, for additional protection.
It is suggested that a light piece of cardboard or blotter be
placed in ench cover, to keep the same in proper shape, and also to act as a
cushion to secure a clear impression of the cachet and
cancellation mark on
the cover.
PAN AMERICAN AIRWAYS COMPANY.
